skill.name: enact/json-formatter
skill.description: Formats and prettifies JSON with configurable indentation
skill.summary: Formats and prettifies JSON with configurable indentation
skill.author: EnactProtocol

security_audit.summary: Static analysis flagged 10 patterns as potential security issues. After evaluation, all findings are FALSE POSITIVES. The 'external_commands' pattern was triggered by code block markers in documentation examples, not actual command execution. The 'weak cryptographic algorithm' patterns were false positives likely caused by JSON field names or schema keywords. This is a simple JSON formatting utility with no network, filesystem, or command execution risks beyond standard script execution.

medium_findings.title: False Positive: Documentation Code Block Markers
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected 'Ruby/shell backtick execution' at SKILL.md:52, 54, 65. These are markdown code block markers (```bash, ```json) in documentation examples, not actual backtick command execution. The skill documentation shows example usage but contains no shell command injection vectors.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Markdown code block delimiters are not shell backticks; the documented command examples are static usage instructions with no user input interpolation

medium_findings.title: False Positive: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm Detection
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected 'weak cryptographic algorithm' at SKILL.md:5, 15, 19, 28, 31, 34. These lines contain JSON schema field descriptions like 'JSON string to format' and 'Error message if invalid JSON'. No cryptographic code, hashing, or encryption exists in this skill.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Lines contain only schema descriptions; no cryptographic functions, hashing, or encryption algorithms are present in the codebase

medium_findings.title: False Positive: System Reconnaissance Pattern
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged 'system reconnaissance' at SKILL.md:31. Line 31 contains 'description: Whether the input was valid JSON' in the output schema. No system scanning, reconnaissance, or information gathering code exists.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Line contains a JSON schema field description; the word 'system' appears nowhere and no reconnaissance patterns are present

content.value_statement: JSON data is difficult to read when minified or improperly formatted. This skill validates and prettifies JSON strings with user-specified indentation to improve readability for debugging, logging, and data inspection.
actual_capabilities: Parses and validates JSON input strings
Formats JSON with configurable indentation (1-8 spaces)
Provides error messages for invalid JSON input
limitations: Does not modify JSON in place; only formats provided input
Cannot validate JSON against a schema
Does not compress or minify JSON
Cannot convert between JSON and other formats like YAML

use_cases.title: Format API responses for debugging
use_cases.description: Quickly format raw API responses or logged JSON output to identify structure and locate errors in complex nested objects.

use_cases.title: Clean up configuration data
use_cases.description: Transform minified or single-line JSON configuration files into readable multi-line format for easier editing and version control.

use_cases.title: Validate incoming JSON data
use_cases.description: Check if a string is valid JSON and get formatted output for inspection when working with user input or external data sources.

prompt_templates.title: Basic JSON formatting
prompt_templates.prompt:
Use the enact/json-formatter skill to format this JSON with 2-space indentation:

${json_input}
prompt_templates.scenario: Formatting a JSON string with default 2-space indentation

prompt_templates.title: Compact formatting with custom indent
prompt_templates.prompt:
Use enact/json-formatter with ${indent} spaces to format:

${json_input}

prompt_templates.title: Format and validate unknown JSON
prompt_templates.prompt:
Check if this is valid JSON and format it nicely:

${raw_json}
prompt_templates.scenario: Validating and formatting unknown JSON data

prompt_templates.title: Format large JSON payloads
prompt_templates.prompt:
Format this JSON document with ${indent} indentation for better readability:

${large_json}
prompt_templates.scenario: Formatting large JSON payloads with custom indentation

best_practices: Use 2-space indentation for general readability and consistency with common style guides
Use 4-space indentation for deeply nested structures to visualize hierarchy more clearly
Validate JSON before formatting to catch syntax errors early
anti_patterns: Using this skill to format JSON from untrusted sources without validation first
Expecting schema validation; this tool only checks JSON syntax, not structure
Formatting very large JSON payloads without considering timeout limits

faq.question: What indentation options are supported?
faq.answer: The skill accepts any integer value for indentation. Common choices are 2 (default) or 4 spaces. Higher values like 8 may be used for very large nested objects.

faq.question: Does this skill modify files on disk?
faq.answer: No. The skill only processes the JSON string provided as input and returns formatted output. It does not read or write any files.

faq.question: Can I use this to format JSON from an API response?
faq.answer: Yes. Pass the API response body as the json parameter. The skill will validate and format it regardless of whether it was minified.

faq.question: What happens with invalid JSON?
faq.answer: The skill returns valid: false and includes an error message describing the JSON syntax error. This helps identify issues in the input data.

faq.question: Is there a size limit for JSON input?
faq.answer: The skill runs with a 30-second timeout. Very large JSON files (megabytes) may approach this limit depending on system resources.

faq.question: Does this skill support JSON5 or other JSON variants?
faq.answer: No. This skill uses standard JSON.parse and JSON.stringify, which only support strict JSON syntax. Comments and trailing commas are not allowed.
